cohort.description: Owns former eastern Canada and western Greenland. Very temperate and fertile areas now.
Owns former Alaska and western and central Canada. A thriving and comfortable place to live.
Owns central and eastern North America, except for the Virginia-New-England Nuclear Exclusion Zone. Northern regions are the only regions that are habitable, productive and fertile.
Owns the western coast of South America, with its high mountains and remaining rain forests. It has low population density and is far from any nuclear exclusion zones, so life is comfortable.
Owns the southwestern coast of North America and most of central America. The equatorial regions are inhospitable except at high altitudes. Seismic activity makes former California undesirable.
Owns the northern and eastern coast of South America including former Brazil. The largest remaining repository of rainforests. Temperatures are a challenge, but this is still a productive region.

Owns the inhabitable parts of Africa south of the desertification region. Population groups are small and widely spread due to the hot climate. Remains a technological powerhouse due to mineral wealth and high levels of education.

Owns Europe north of the desertification region and east of the Franco-British Nuclear Exclusion Zone. The Northern region is quite nice. The Southern regions are barely habitable due to fallout from the Middle Eastern Nuclear Exclusion Zone.
Owns the bulk of south and east Asia. Climate ranges from ideal to inhospitable. Dual Nuclear Exclusion Zones make the northwest a challenging area to live.
Owns island real estate around the world. Former Iceland and New Zealand are habitable despite their proximity to Nuclear Exclusion Zones.
Owns former eastern Greenland. Climate is ideal, and there is plenty of space.
